title: Do French people like it when Americans speak French? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, it is nice when an American makes an effort. I will assist if they need it. And if they need to revert to English, no big deal. I have an erstwhile colleague who speaks very good French, and does so with facility, but he was born in the San Francisco Bay Area, and he has the most astounding California accent in French that I have ever heard. If I let myself dwell on this, it can be distracting… Nevertheless, if he wanted to speak French, I was happy to oblige. It showed that he had made an effort to learn the language, and it showed that he cared enough to try to learn something about the culture and the people. Bravo for him. Every language we learn opens a door.

When I speak French in France, the locals generally respond with appreciation. My husband, whose French is quite faulty (sometimes hilariously so), and who speaks it with a very broad midwestern American accent, has also gotten appreciative reactions from French people. That’s natural, I think. As an ER nurse, I often care for patients who don’t speak English. When they’re discharged, many of them manage an English “Thank you,” often heavily accented but intelligible. I always appreciate that effort, however limited, to communicate with me in my own language. I think that’s probably a universal feeling, don’t you?
